question.name: 19.3.2.8 Complementary Func Ex1
question.questiontext:
Exercise

Obtain the general solutions, that is, the complementary functions, of the following equations:

  1. \(\displaystyle {@ODE1@}\).

    \({@y1@}_{\text{cf}} =\) \(A\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] \(+\) \(B\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] . [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(\displaystyle {@ODE2@}\).

    \({@y2@}_{\text{cf}} =\) \(A\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] \(+\) \(B\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] . [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(\displaystyle {@ODE3@}\). In your final answer, factor out the term \(e^{\alpha {@x3@}}\).

    \({@y3@}_{\text{cf}} =\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] \(\times\) \(\bigg( A\) [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]] \(+ B\) [[input:ans7]] [[validation:ans7]] \(\bigg)\). [[feedback:prt3]]

  4. \(\displaystyle {@ODE4@}\). In your final answer, factor out the term \(e^{\alpha {@x3@}}\).

    \({@y4@}_{\text{cf}} =\) [[input:ans8]] [[validation:ans8]] \(\times\) \(\bigg( A\) [[input:ans9]] [[validation:ans9]] \(+ B\) [[input:ans10]] [[validation:ans10]] \(\bigg)\). [[feedback:prt4]]

  5. \(\displaystyle {@ODE5@}\).

    \({@y5@}_{\text{cf}} =\) \(A\) [[input:ans11]] [[validation:ans11]] \(+\) \(B\) [[input:ans12]] [[validation:ans12]] . [[feedback:prt5]]
question.generalfeedback:
1. We are given the equation \(\displaystyle {@ODE1@}\). Using the substitution \({@y1@} = e^{k{@x1@}}\) we obtain the auxiliary equation \(k^2 - {@aa1+bb1@}k + {@aa1*bb1@} = 0\).

    Solving the auxiliary equation we obtain \(k = {@aa1@}\) and \(k = {@bb1@}\). Therefore, since we have two distinct real roots, we have two solutions \({@y1@} = e^{{@aa1*x1@}}\) and \({@y1@} = e^{{@bb1*x1@}}\). Therefore the general solution is \[{@y1@}_{\text{cf}} = A{@ta1@} + B{@ta2@}.\]

  2. We are given the equation \(\displaystyle {@ODE2@}\). Using the substitution \({@y2@} = e^{k{@x2@}}\) we obtain the auxiliary equation \(k^2 + {@-aa2-bb2@}k + {@aa2*bb2@} = 0\).

    Solving the auxiliary equation we obtain \(k = {@aa2@}\) with multiplicity \(2\). Recall that if the auxiliary equation has two equal roots, \(k\), then the complementary function is \({@y2@}_{\text{cf}} = (A + B)e^{k{@x1@}}\). Therefore the general solution is \[{@y2@}_{\text{cf}} = A{@ta3@} + B{@ta4@}.\]

  3. We are given the equation \(\displaystyle {@ODE3@}\). Using the substitution \({@y3@} = e^{k{@x3@}}\) we obtain the auxiliary equation \(k^2 + {@aa3@}k + {@bb3@} = 0\).

    Solving this using the quadratic formula yields \[k = {@-aa3/2@} \pm {@roots3@}.\]

    Recall that if the auxiliary equation has complex roots \(\alpha + \beta \mathrm{i}\) and \(\alpha - \beta \mathrm{i}\), then the complementary function is \[{@y3@}_{\text{cf}} = e^{\alpha {@x3@}}\left( A\cos\beta{@x3@} + B\sin\beta{@x3@} \right).\] Therefore the general solution is \[{@y3@}_{\text{cf}} = {@ta5@}\left(A{@ta6@} + B{@ta7@}\right).\]

  4. We are given the equation \(\displaystyle {@ODE4@}\). Using the substitution \({@y4@} = e^{k{@x4@}}\) we obtain the auxiliary equation \(k^2 + {@bb4^2@} = 0\).

    Solving the auxiliary equation yields the two solutions \(k = {@bb4@}\mathrm{i}\) and \(k = -{@bb4@}\mathrm{i}\).

    Again, recall that if the auxiliary equation has complex roots \(\alpha + \beta \mathrm{i}\) and \(\alpha - \beta \mathrm{i}\), then the complementary function is \[{@y4@}_{\text{cf}} = e^{\alpha {@x4@}}\left( A\cos\beta{@x4@} + B\sin\beta{@x4@} \right).\] Therefore the general solution is \[ {@y4@}_{\text{cf}} = {@ta8@}(A{@ta9@} + B{@ta10@}).\]

  5. We are given the equation \(\displaystyle {@ODE5@}\). Using the substitution \({@y5@} = e^{k{@x5@}}\) we obtain the auxiliary equation \(k^2 - {@bb5^2@} = 0\).

    Solving the auxiliary equation yields the two solutions \(k = {@bb5@}\) and \(k = -{@bb5@}\). These are two distinct real roots, therefore the general solution is \[{@y5@}_{\text{cf}} = A{@ta11@} + B{@ta12@}.\]

stackoptions.prtcorrect: Correct answer, well done.
stackoptions.prtpartiallycorrect: Your answer is partially correct.
stackoptions.prtincorrect: Incorrect answer.
